newsitem.title: SPAIN: PRESS DIGEST - Chinese newspapers - July 25.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Chinese newspapers - July 25.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Chinese political and business stories in leading newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Beijing. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy. Telephone: (8610) 6532-1921. Fax:
PEOPLE'S DAILY
- President Jiang Zemin stresses importance of family planning and environmental protection, saying both closely related to China's overall social and economic development.
- Premier Li Peng says population problem remains serious despite some achievements last year, and family planning must receive due attention every year.
- President Jiang Zemin tells former U.S. President Jimmy Carter that opportunity exists for further growth in bilateral ties
- In northern Fushun, 20,000 laid-off staff find new jobs in first half
- Book titled Fluttering the Army Flag to be published to mark the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Liberation Army
XINHUA DAILY TELEGRAPH
- Premier Li Peng tells former U.S. President Jimmy Carter that two countries should continue efforts to place bilateral relations on a more stable and healthy basis.
CHINA SECURITIES
- Economist Dong Furen says state-owned firms must adapt to market economy
- Customs figures show natural rubber imports down 20.55 pct in June
- Beijing gross domestic product up 11.2 percent in first half
FINANCIAL NEWS
- Industrial and Commercial Bank of Chian prepares 270 million yuan as domestic loan to support World Bank housing reform project
- China Securities Regulatory Commission rescinds licences of seven brokerage houses.
ECONOMIC INFORMATION DAILY
- Ministry of Agriculture calls for preventing bollworm disaster that could hit north China in August
- Wuhan Iron and Steel Co attributes heavy losses to steel smuggling from Russia
- Private vehicles will account for 48.9 percent of sales this year
CHINA DAILY
- China and Japan should work for the healthy and stable development of ties, Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Premier Li Peng tell form Japanese Prime Minister Morihoro Hosokawa.
